Title.evidence: Methods: In this randomized controlled trial, elderly patients (aged ≥ 60 years) undergoing elective TKA were randomly allocated in a 1:1:1 ratio to 0.6 μg/kg/h dexmedetomidine (Group D2), 0.3 μg/kg/h dexmedetomidine (Group D1) and saline (Group N).

Trial_Design.evidence: Methods: In this randomized controlled trial, elderly patients (aged ≥ 60 years) undergoing elective TKA were randomly allocated in a 1:1:1 ratio to 0.6 μg/kg/h dexmedetomidine (Group D2), 0.3 μg/kg/h dexmedetomidine (Group D1) and saline (Group N).

Participants.evidence: elderly patients (aged ≥ 60 years) undergoing elective TKA

Intervention.evidence: randomly allocated in a 1:1:1 ratio to 0.6 μg/kg/h dexmedetomidine (Group D2), 0.3 μg/kg/h dexmedetomidine (Group D1) and saline (Group N).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine the effects of different doses of dexmedetomidine on postoperative QoR in elderly TKA patients, and whether there is a correlation with specific EEG changes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: On postoperative days 1 and 3, the15-item Quality of Recovery (QoR-15) scale was used to evaluate the postoperative recovery of patients among the three groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The difference of QoR-15 scores on postoperative day 1 was significant for Group D2 vs Group N (126 [123–129] points vs 120 [116–123] points; median difference, 6 points [95% CI, 4 to 8]; P < 0.001) and Group D2 vs Group D1 (126 [123–129] points vs 122 [118–126]; median difference, 4 points [95% CI, 2 to 5]; P = 0.001)
